text: (upbeat music)
- My name is Tom Godden.
I'm an Enterprise Strategist with AWS.
I'm a former Chief Information Officer
at Foundation Medicine,

and I'm really excited
about this opportunity.

I'm joined here by Aamer
Baig, partner at McKinsey.

Would you tell us a little
bit about your background
and your excitement about generative AI?
- Thank you, Tom.
I'm a senior partner at McKinsey.

I lead McKinsey's technology
practice globally.

That's our client service
for the CIO/CTO community.
We advise the C-suite
on tech-enabled business transformations.
And there's nothing more exciting now

than looking at the power of
generative AI and the cloud

to really drive different
business outcomes,
so that's what gets me really excited.

- Can you share from your
perspective what it means to be,
you know, what generative AI means?
What's the business value?

What are we looking at when
we're looking at generative AI?
- It's a great question.
Generative AI has the promise of being

what we would call a
generational technology
and really allow businesses and functions
to really reimagine themselves.
So what we believe is

it's an evolution across many
years of development of AI,
and this is the next step,
where you have a field of AI

that actually generates
content, synthesizes content,

and can do a lot of other
very powerful things.
The value for enterprises

is mainly in productivity,
but also in creativity.
At McKinsey, we looked at 63 use cases
across a number of functions,

and when you ask about
value, think of this number.

That the value is about
2.6 to 4.4 trillion
in economic impact.
- Wow.
- That's the power of this technology
or the promise of this technology.
You would say, then ask the question,
"Where does it come from?
Among the 63 use cases, about 75% of this
is coming from four functions,
sales and marketing, R and D,

software engineering,
and customer operations.
- [Tom] Okay.
- So these are the four that we believe

will be the most
fundamentally transformed.

- And why is that the case
for those? Why those four?
I mean, it makes sense.

Target-rich environments
it feels like, but why?
Why are those four the important four?
- Well, you have to think about
where the actual craft
and the activities in these functions
can actually be reimagined or transformed
using a new technology, so-

- Can we talk about
that for just a second?

- Yeah.
- You know,
we see this a lot with organizations
that rush into that new technology,
and they use that new technology
to just redo what they used to do.

And then they're like, "Oh,
I didn't get the value,
"the aha, out of it."
It's when you use the new technology
to completely reimagine the process.
So dive into that a little bit more,
'cause I think that's so crucial

as we look at how do we get
value outta generative AI.
- Yeah, let's take some of the examples.
I grew up as a developer and wrote code.

Coding and software engineering
is an apprenticeship model
once you've learned the basics, right?

So, you know, how powerful is
it to have someone next to you

that can suggest what
the next line of code is
or help you with testing or documentation.
It really propels you to a different level
of performance and productivity.
Now let's take something very different.
If you are a customer service rep,
you get all these calls.
You have to process a lot of information
and react to it in real time.

How wonderful would it be
that you get suggestions
on what the potential answer could be,

to which you can actually
apply your own human judgment
and then help the customer?
Take another example.
In R and D, coming up with new designs,
new formulations, new blueprints
has always been learned over time.

How great would it be
that you have a technology

that can assist with new
combinations of that?
- This technology is going to really help

propel people to new levels
of creativity and efficiency.

It's going to be an
incredibly positive thing,
but people are still worried, right?
They're worried.

They have concerns,
and their concerns are,

let's be honest, they're
real, they're valid.
But how are you seeing organizations

help people get comfortable
with this technology and realize

this is about letting the
computers do what it does well
so the humans can do what they do well,
and not a replacement in most cases?
How are you seeing that play out?
- First, it's important to acknowledge

that there is still a
little bit of I would say
jitteriness about this, as you mentioned.

But at the same time,
we're seeing enterprises

invest behind this because
the potential is quite high.

So we actually think there
are three important strategies
that will help with that.
One is your posture and frame of reference

as far as the potential
for this opportunity.
If it's a human-assisted technology,

human-empowered technology,
which is what I believe,

I think it opens the aperture
and opens minds and hearts.
That's one.

The second is it has
to also be followed up

with an emphasis on
scaling up the right people

to be able to deal with-
- Train your people.
Train your people.

Train your people.
- Train, exactly.

And then the third is to
adopt a set of policies

that will also give comfort
but protect people as well.
- Elaborate on that.
- So, you wanna make sure that people
are using information safely.

- Okay.
- Right?
You also want to follow through,

especially if it is a
customer facing application,

that you're checking
for things like toxicity
in content that's being generated.
You are putting the right guardrails

around mistakes that sometimes
this technology still makes.

So that all will be collectively
confidence boosting.

- Yeah, and I think it's
important when you do that

and you're talking about
responsible AI program.
And I tell people,

step one needs to be build
a responsible AI program.

You can't let the horse, the
cow, whatever, out of the barn
and then try to go get it back.
And candidly, I think maybe we did that
a little bit with social media,
where we let it get out in front of us,
and then we've had to pull it back
from a privacy standpoint.
- You're absolutely right,
and then that requires a different mindset

and operating model within
the organization as well.
So, for example, we're seeing
a lot of very rapid progress
in pursuing POCs,
but a slower
take-up or a slower sort of rollout
from POC testing into production.
- How are organizations approaching going,

"Where do I put those bets on
the right proof of concept,

"the right ideas, so that
they can become something,
"and then so I can scale them?"
One of the things

that I see people struggling
with is just the why.
They're doing candidly cool things,

but not cool things that
necessarily deliver business value,
which candidly should be what we're doing.
How are you seeing people approach that

and look at it and go,
"Where do I put those bets?"

- I think it's an important
management challenge right now,
is to both

allow for some
experimentation and learning,

but also really place your bets
where it makes a difference.
So where-
- Lots of rapid experiments at low cost.
- A lot of rapid experiments at low cost,
but really putting your energy
behind a few bets that work, right?

So we're suggesting a two-by-two
approach, which is pick two
where you can make an impact very quickly,
so you actually have some learning
that you can actually go forward with.

- Sure.
- And two, where you believe

it could be game changing
for your business.
And it doesn't have to be two,
but it's a small, manageable number.

Because where you're
gonna bet the business,
you wanna be right, right?
Where the risk reward/equation is, right?

And you wanna make sure that
you have everything in place,
and then you go for the big hit.

- Yeah, so what's your
favorite example, if I can,

where you went, "That's-
- So-
- "pretty clever."

- So, I go back to what I was
trained out of school to do,
which is in software engineering, right?

I actually think the
opportunity closest at hand
is how we can really drive
developer productivity using this-
- I love that one.
There's very few things as a CIO
that have made me just go, "Wow."
And when I look at the productivity gains
with things like Amazon CodeWhisperer,
you know, it just, it blows me away.
57% increase in productivity.
27% more likely to be successful.

How can you not be
adopting that technology?
It's unbelievable.
- It is, it seems like a win-win-win.
- It sure does.

- It's a win because
you can do a lot more.

- Yeah.
- It's a win

because you can do a lot
more at a higher quality.

- Yeah.
- And it's also a win

when we've actually done
research and tested this.
The developer experience
also increases when done right, right?
So, you have the core audience liking it
and the enterprise benefiting as well.

- You know, the other win
that I'd throw on top of that
is you get the creative juices flowing.
So you get the software engineer

who's starting to use that
going, "Gosh, if I can use that

"inside of my development
environment to do things,
"I wonder if the contact center agent

"could also benefit in
a similar type of way?"
Different, but in a similar type of way,
and so it starts to get people experienced
in using this and getting familiar with it

and overcoming a little
bit maybe of that fear,

that mystery of that
unknown to be able to do it.

Can we talk about the
foundation here a little bit?

Everyone sees the
examples of generative AI.

They get excited about
it. Why wouldn't you?
I would. I get excited about it.

But it's kinda like the
tip of the iceberg, right?

There's a lot under the
water that needs to be done.

In particular, you gotta
get your data right.

You know, if you don't have
a strong data foundation,
it's gonna be hard for you to be able
to take advantage of these things.

Share a little bit what
you're seeing with people
and what they're doing with data,

maybe what they're doing well,
maybe what they need to do

in order to really capitalize
on this and to be a success.
- It seems like
it's a perennial problem that is,
which is data quality and data management
and availability of the right data.

It was important before, but
it's even more important now
and it's coming into sharp relief.
It's not an exaggeration to say
that whatever you want to do with AI,
not just generative AI,

is gated by the data you
you feed into the models

and how the data is
actually used coming out.
So the foundations you talk about
are exceptionally important.
We think the effort to build the right
data ecosystem
is an important down payment

for getting the benefit
out of generative AI.
In addition to that, we think there's

some new elements in any
tech stack for an enterprise
that have to be worked in, right?
So for example, there's a lot of talk

about large language
models, which one to use?
When? Why?
But how do you access that?
How do you

train people how to you use
the right prompts, right?
You need an API layer to access the LLMs.
Do you then also

want to keep a library of
good prompts, for example,

so by a certain use case
so people can use that?

So all these things have
to be thought through
as part of the foundation, right,
that's built on good data.

- Yeah, and we really believe
that there's not gonna be
one large language model to rule them all.
We think that people are gonna need
different models for different use cases.
We also think it's early days

and there's gonna be a lot
of change in these models.

- One more strategy we're
seeing with some companies

is they're thinking of horses
for courses strategy as well
for, you know, some situations
where your proprietary data is not used.

Maybe one large language
model is appropriate

when something is closer
to your crown jewels,
your crown jewels being your data,
your institutional knowledge, right?

People are being quite
careful about what to use,
and

the statement measure
twice, cut once applies,

so a lot more testing and
analysis is happening there.

How do you see this
changing the IT organization
in the future and the role of the CIO?
- Yeah, it's really interesting,

'cause I think this, along
with a lot of other change,
is really driving a need to get closer
to the opportunity to the business need.
You know, and so the days of a large,
centralized IT organization

that's building common
platforms to every build on,

that, by the way, I spent 30
years as CIO trying to perfect.
I never did.

Never did. I did it right,
but we didn't perfect them.
They're hard to do,

those centralized ones.
- Which you aim
for perfection.

- I aim for perfection.
- Yes.
- It's really, you know,

maybe an overused term,
democratizing IT, you know?

But it's putting the
importance of how can I become
more agile, more directly connected
to the rest of the organization?
You know, a term that drives me nuts
is when people say "the business,"
I'm like, "Gosh, who's the?"

Why are we doing this as
IT? We do it to ourselves.
You don't say marketing in the business,
sales in the business.
We just say IT in the business.

What this is doing is it's
making us realize that technology

should be embedded in
almost every single thing
an organization does.
And so as part of that,

it's a massive
decentralization I think of IT.
I dunno, what's your perspective on that?
- It's similar.
I would start by saying first,

anytime there was a
generational technology,

one of the secondary effects
of that has been on the impact
of an IT function in companies, right?
So you have mainframe computing
that led to the rise of an IT department.
Then you had the internet,

which basically allowed us
to access offshore locations

because you have bandwidth
and you have availability,

and the rise of various
different providers.
Then you had cloud and mobile, right,

you could argue that
propelled the adoption
of product and platform operating models
and how IT organizations
are structured.

And then you have the I
would say proliferation

or the mass adoption of
AI coming in this decade.
So I land in a similar place that you do,

which is technology will
no longer be a function,
it'll be a capability.

- I like it.
- Right?

So a capability that's
embedded in every aspects
of how you deliver value to the customer.

And as a result, I too would
like to ban the IT or business.

And I like to say IT
equals business equals IT.
- There you go.
- Another question for you.

- Yeah, okay.
- Yeah.
As you sat in your chair as a CIO

and now you look at this,
if you were a CIO now,
what would give you concern
and what would give you excitement here?

- You know, one of the
things that gives me concern
coming from life sciences is the perceived

randomness of the potential
answers you could get
from a generative AI.

And needing back to the
regulators, have control.
And so you sit there and go,

"Gosh, I love all the
potential and everything,

"but I just can't have it
generating answers," you know?

And so that gives me
a lot of pause for it.

Now, with that said, I
think there are techniques

that can solve that,
RAG being one of them,
retrieval-augmented generation.

You can query a known
repository of answers,

but still get the rich,
contextual dialogue,
you know, information of that answer,

but make sure that the
answer is always blue,

'cause that's the approved
answer, not green.
Please don't freelance. Blue's the answer.

And so I think that there
are some ways to do that.

I think they still need to be
proven out to the regulators

that that will be enough
control over that.

But when you talk about,
well, what excites me on it,
we talked about the developer one.
That certainly excites me on it.

But I think just the
ability to democratize IT.

You know, one of the
things, when you put power
in the hands of the people,

it's one of the best
things that you could do.

And what excites me about
this is all the ideas
don't have to come from one group.

They don't have to come
just from technology.

They don't have to just come
from your data scientists.

They don't just have to come
from the executive suite.
We have the ability with this technology
to allow every single person

to be able to start to
explore and to utilize it,
so that really gets to excite me.

But then see my first
response also, which is,
okay, now that I've democratized it
and given it to everyone,

but I need it to maintain a
little bit of control over it.
So it is that-

- Scaffolding.
- push and pull.
Well, the scaffolding's important.
That's how you manage it, right?
And a strong, responsible AI program,

strong oversight by the
human is able to do that.
What excites you?
- I think
there have been some intractable problems
in enterprise technology,
so I feel like this has given us a chance

to start attacking them at a
cost that might be manageable.
So the three that come to mind,
one is tech debt.

- Yeah.
- Okay?

We seem to accumulate more
and more every year, right?

So, and one reason for that
is the cost of software

and cost of software development
never actually went down.

Maybe it does now and we
can actually deal with it.
That's one.
Second is talent.
We've always had a dearth of talent.

I'm actually excited about
more work getting done

with the talent we have
while driving the experience
of the developers.
- And I think it's gonna create jobs
we haven't even contemplated.

- And we haven't, yeah,
that's a great point.

And then the third,
we've always had an issue

delivering large tech-enabled
projects on time, right?
- That never happened to me.
- Of course, yes.

So I'm hopeful that there's
some interesting applications
of generative AI that can actually solve
some of these intractable problems.
- Yeah, I think finally the technology's
ready to meet the moment.
I think we over promised, right,
as an IT organization on what we could do,
which led then into the knots,
a contraction of IT.
IT was a cost to be managed.

You know, I'm gonna, "How can
I do this for less money?"
It's, you know, it's not going away,
but I also don't want to pay a lot for it.

And I think finally with the
cloud and the advent of cloud

and the movement towards
more agile type of thinking
and now a generative AI,

I think we're ready to meet
the moment to finally be able

to tackle some of those things
that you've talked about.

I really enjoyed the dialogue,
